###Objectives of this PhD work <br />

###**General aim**
 - To identify epigenetic marks associated with psychosis and treatment effects <br />

###**Specific aims**
  -  Investigate time-of-blood draw on cell-type proportions 
  -  Common and specific effects of antipsychotic drugs 
  -  Disorder specific effects of SCZ vs BPD

###Characteristics of DNAm  <br> <br>

.enlarge[
- Essential role in tissue differentiation (Reike) <br> <br>
- Key role in determining transcription factor binding and enhancer function (Ziller) <br> <br>
- Highly malleable; influenced by many environmental exposures, i.e. levels of _in utero_ nutrients and smoking <br> <br>
- Overtime changes as a function of age, cancer, and complex diseases <br> 
]

###Project 1
###Does time-of-blood draw impact the association of SCZ vs controls on cell-type proportions?

.pull-right[.footnote[Eug√®ne Gabritschevsky, _Untitled_,1947]]


---

###Methods <br> <br>

.enlarge[
1. Selected SCZ cases & controls with recorded time-of-blood draw (n=729) <br> <br>
1. Estimated cell-type proportions from DNAm data  *Salas _et al.,_ 2018* <br> <br>
1. Compared linear regression models when adjusting for blood draw time.  <br> <br>
1. Compared full day vs half day <br> <br>
1. Sub-analyses: Neutrophil-to-lympocyte ratio / Medication-free SCZ
]

#Technical Challenges


There is currently no standardized EWAS pipeline for analysis. Findings from other research groups must be considered for study design, population, technical methods including:
 - Microarry (Illumina 450K vs. EPIC - 850K) 
 - Bisulfite sequencing
 - 
 - Small sample sizes vs. meta-analyses
 - Methods of detecting DMRs
 - Pathway analysis 
 
 - something about QC and singularity issue with small sample size (insert image here of microarray)
 ???
 say something about bias for genes associated with cancer 
 Sugden paper

---


class: left top 
#Scientific Challenges

- We can never control for all environmental factors that may influence the mental state of the individuals being studied. 

- The data available to us is derived from one blood sample. 
 
- We need improved statistical tools to gain deeper understanding of our findings, especially when we have smaller sample sizes (i.e., target monotherapies). 

- DNAm is dynamic and longitudinal studies are necessary to gain a more complete picture of the environmental impact being studied.
